class="md-article-container container template-large_paginated">            <h1>Nanotechnology</h1><div class="md-byline">	<div class="written-by">			<span>Written By: </span>			<ul>				<li><a href="/contributor/S-Tom-Picraux/5756">S. Tom Picraux</a></li>				</ul>			</div>	<div class="last-updated hidden-xs">			<span>Last Updated: </span>				<time datetime="2018-03-14">3-14-2018</time>			<a data-type="accordion-link" href="#accordion-article-history" rel="nofollow">See Article History</a>			</div>	</div><div class="grid">				<div class="grid-sm">					<article id="article-content" class="content"><section id="ref1" data-level="1"><p><strong><span id="ref836137"></span>Nanotechnology</strong>,  the manipulation and manufacture of materials and devices on the scale of atoms or small groups of atoms. The “<span id="ref836956"></span>nanoscale” is typically measured in nanometres, or billionths of a metre (<em>nanos</em>, the Greek word for “dwarf,” being the source of the prefix), and materials built at this scale often exhibit distinctive physical and chemical properties due to <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/quantum-mechanics-physics" class="md-crosslink">quantum mechanical</a> effects. Although usable devices this small may be decades away (<em>see</em> <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/microelectromechanical-system" class="md-crosslink">microelectromechanical system</a>), techniques for working at the nanoscale have become essential to electronic <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/engineering" class="md-crosslink autoxref">engineering</a>, and nanoengineered materials have begun to appear in consumer products. For example, billions of microscopic “<span id="ref836957"></span>nanowhiskers,” each about 10 nanometres in length, have been molecularly hooked onto natural and <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/synthetic" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="synthetic">synthetic</a> fibres to impart stain resistance to <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/dress-clothing" class="md-crosslink autoxref">clothing</a> and other fabrics; zinc oxide nanocrystals have been used to create invisible sunscreens that block ultraviolet light; and silver nanocrystals have been embedded in bandages to kill bacteria and prevent infection.</p><!--[P1]--><ul class="assemblies medialist" data-type="other"><li><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="73082"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/88/79488-004-E2C535A2.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/88/79488-004-E2C535A2.jpg" alt="Examples from biological and mechanical realms illustrate various “orders of magnitude” (powers of 10), from 10−2 metre down to 10−7 metre." data-width="694" data-height="540"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Examples from biological and mechanical realms illustrate various “orders of magnitude” (powers of 10), from 10<sup>−2</sup> metre down to 10<sup>−7</sup> metre.</span><cite>Illustration: Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc.; photographs:(microelectromechanical devices) Courtesy Sandia National Laboratories, SUMMiT™ Technologies; (quantum corral) courtesy IBM Research Center, unauthorized used not permitted; (red blood cells) Susumu Nishinaga/Science Source; (human hair) Manfred Kage/Peter Arnold, Inc.; (dust mite) Andrew Syred/Science Source</cite></figcaption></figure></li><li><figure data-type="video" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="194274"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="video"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/68/179468-049-50D0201F.jpg" alt="nanotechnology: food processing" data-width="426" data-height="240"></div></div><figcaption><strong class="md-assembly-title">nanotechnology: food processing</strong><span class="md-assembly-caption">Learn about the use of nanotechnology in food processing, including the possible health issues.</span><cite>Contunico © ZDF Enterprises GmbH, Mainz</cite></figcaption></figure></li></ul><!--[ML1]--><p>Possibilities for the future are numerous. Nanotechnology may make it possible to manufacture lighter, stronger, and programmable materials that require less energy to produce than conventional materials, that produce less waste than with conventional <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/manufacturing" class="md-crosslink autoxref">manufacturing</a>, and that promise greater fuel <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/efficiency" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="efficiency">efficiency</a> in land <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/transportation-technology" class="md-crosslink autoxref">transportation</a>, ships, aircraft, and space vehicles. Nanocoatings for both <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/opaque" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="opaque">opaque</a> and translucent surfaces may render them resistant to corrosion, scratches, and radiation. Nanoscale electronic, magnetic, and mechanical devices and systems with unprecedented levels of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/information-processing" class="md-crosslink autoxref">information processing</a> may be fabricated, as may chemical, photochemical, and biological sensors for protection, health care, manufacturing, and the environment; new photoelectric materials that will enable the manufacture of cost-efficient solar-energy panels; and molecular-semiconductor hybrid devices that may become engines for the next revolution in the information age. The potential for improvements in health, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/safety-condition" class="md-crosslink autoxref">safety</a>, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/quality-of-life" class="md-crosslink autoxref">quality of life</a>, and conservation of the <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/environment" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="environment">environment</a> are vast.</p><!--[P2]--><p>At the same time, significant challenges must be overcome for the benefits of nanotechnology to be realized. Scientists must learn how to manipulate and characterize individual <span id="ref836959"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/atom" class="md-crosslink">atoms</a> and small groups of atoms reliably. New and improved tools are needed to control the properties and structure of materials at the nanoscale; significant improvements in computer simulations of atomic and molecular structures are essential to the understanding of this realm. Next, new tools and approaches are needed for assembling atoms and molecules into nanoscale systems and for the further assembly of small systems into more-complex objects. Furthermore, nanotechnology products must provide not only improved performance but also lower cost. Finally, without <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/integration" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="integration">integration</a> of nanoscale objects with systems at the micro- and macroscale (that is, from millionths of a metre up to the millimetre scale), it will be very difficult to exploit many of the unique properties found at the nanoscale.</p><!--[P3]--></section><div class="major-reference-upsell">			<iframe src="/GPTIframe/ajax/sync/EB_HOUSE_DESKTOP" scrolling="no" width="640" height="106"></iframe>		</div><section id="ref236432" data-level="1"><h2 class="h1">Overview of nanotechnology</h2><p>Nanotechnology is highly interdisciplinary, involving physics, chemistry, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/biology" class="md-crosslink autoxref">biology</a>, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/materials-science" class="md-crosslink autoxref">materials science</a>, and the full range of the engineering <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/disciplines" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="disciplines">disciplines</a>. The word <em>nanotechnology</em> is widely used as shorthand to refer to both the science and the technology of this emerging field. Narrowly defined, nanoscience concerns a basic understanding of physical, chemical, and biological properties on atomic and near-atomic scales. Nanotechnology, narrowly defined, employs controlled manipulation of these properties to create materials and functional systems with unique capabilities.</p><!--[P4]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="video" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="208471"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="video"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/57/186257-049-7BFAB3B5.jpg" alt="nanotechnology; pharmacology" data-width="426" data-height="240"></div></div><figcaption><strong class="md-assembly-title">nanotechnology; pharmacology</strong><span class="md-assembly-caption">Examining how breakthroughs in nanotechnology are enabling scientists to better understand and apply concepts of particle engineering, specifically in the field of pharmacology.</span><cite>© University of Melbourne, Victoria, Australia</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML4]--><p>In contrast to recent engineering efforts, nature developed “nanotechnologies” over billions of years, employing enzymes and <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/catalysts" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="catalysts">catalysts</a> to organize with <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/exquisite" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="exquisite">exquisite</a> precision different kinds of atoms and molecules into complex microscopic structures that make life possible. These natural products are built with great efficiency and have impressive capabilities, such as the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/power-physics" class="md-crosslink autoxref">power</a> to harvest <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/solar-energy" class="md-crosslink autoxref">solar energy</a>, to convert minerals and water into living cells, to store and process massive amounts of data using large arrays of nerve cells, and to replicate perfectly billions of bits of information stored in molecules of deoxyribonucleic acid (<a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/DNA" class="md-crosslink">DNA</a>).</p><!--[P5]--><p>There are two principal reasons for qualitative differences in material behaviour at the nanoscale (traditionally defined as less than 100 nanometres). First, <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/quantum" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="quantum">quantum</a> mechanical effects come into play at very small dimensions and lead to new physics and chemistry. Second, a defining feature at the nanoscale is the very large surface-to-volume ratio of these structures. This means that no <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/atom" class="md-crosslink autoxref">atom</a> is very far from a surface or interface, and the behaviour of atoms at these higher-energy sites have a significant influence on the properties of the material. For example, the reactivity of a <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/metal-chemistry" class="md-crosslink autoxref">metal</a> <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/catalyst" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="catalyst">catalyst</a> particle generally increases appreciably as its size is reduced—macroscopic <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/gold-chemical-element" class="md-crosslink autoxref">gold</a> is chemically inert, whereas at nanoscales gold becomes extremely reactive and catalytic and even melts at a lower temperature. Thus, at nanoscale dimensions material properties depend on and change with size, as well as <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/composition" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="composition">composition</a> and structure.</p><!--[P6]--><p>Using the processes of nanotechnology, basic industrial production may veer dramatically from the course followed by steel plants and chemical factories of the past. Raw materials will come from the atoms of abundant elements—carbon, hydrogen, and silicon—and these will be manipulated into precise configurations to create nanostructured materials that exhibit exactly the right properties for each particular application. For example, carbon atoms can be bonded together in a number of different geometries to create variously a <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/fiber-technology" class="md-crosslink autoxref">fibre</a>, a tube, a molecular coating, or a wire, all with the superior strength-to-weight ratio of another carbon material—diamond. Additionally, such material processing need not require smokestacks, power-hungry industrial <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/machine" class="md-crosslink autoxref">machinery</a>, or intensive human labour. Instead, it may be accomplished either by “growing” new structures through some combination of chemical catalysts and synthetic enzymes or by building them through new techniques based on patterning and self-assembly of nanoscale materials into useful predetermined designs. Nanotechnology ultimately may allow people to fabricate almost any type of material or product allowable under the laws of physics and chemistry. While such possibilities seem remote, even approaching nature’s virtuosity in energy-efficient fabrication would be revolutionary.</p><!--[P7]--><p>Even more revolutionary would be the fabrication of nanoscale machines and devices for incorporation into micro- and macroscale systems. Once again, nature has led the way with the fabrication of both linear and rotary molecular motors. These biological machines carry out such tasks as muscle contraction (in organisms ranging from clams to humans) and shuttling little packets of material around within cells while being powered by the recyclable, energy-efficient fuel <span id="ref836960"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/adenosine-triphosphate" class="md-crosslink">adenosine triphosphate</a>. Scientists are only beginning to develop the tools to fabricate functioning systems at such small scales, with most advances based on electronic or magnetic information processing and storage systems. The energy-efficient, reconfigurable, and self-repairing aspects of biological systems are just becoming understood.</p><!--[P8]--><p>The potential impact of nanotechnology processes, machines, and products is expected to be far-reaching, affecting nearly every conceivable information technology, energy source, agricultural product, medical device, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/pharmaceutical" class="md-crosslink autoxref">pharmaceutical</a>, and material used in manufacturing. Meanwhile, the dimensions of electronic circuits on semiconductors continue to shrink, with minimum feature sizes now reaching the nanorealm, under 100 nanometres. Likewise, magnetic memory materials, which form the basis of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/hard-disk" class="md-crosslink autoxref">hard disk</a> drives, have achieved dramatically greater memory density as a result of nanoscale structuring to exploit new magnetic effects at nanodimensions. These latter two areas represent another major trend, the evolution of critical elements of microtechnology into the realm of nanotechnology to <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/enhance" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="enhance">enhance</a> performance. They are immense markets driven by the rapid advance of information technology.</p><!--[P9]--></section><!--[H3]--><section id="ref236433" data-level="1"><h2 class="h1">Milestones in the development of nanotechnology</h2><section id="ref236434" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2">Visionaries</h2><p>In a lecture in 1959 to the American Physical Society, “There’s Plenty of Room at the Bottom,” American Nobelist <span id="ref836961"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Richard-Feynman" class="md-crosslink">Richard P. Feynman</a> presented his audience with a vision of what could be done with extreme miniaturization. He began his lecture by noting that the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Lords-Prayer" class="md-crosslink">Lord’s Prayer</a> had been written on the head of a pin and asked,</p><!--[P10]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="video" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="208240"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="video"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/08/186008-049-A072A34E.jpg" alt="Feynman, Richard P.; quantum electrodynamics; nanotechnology" data-width="426" data-height="240"></div></div><figcaption><strong class="md-assembly-title">Feynman, Richard P.; quantum electrodynamics; nanotechnology</strong><span class="md-assembly-caption">Using <em>QED</em>, a play about physicist Richard Feynman, to teach science and engineering.</span><cite>Courtesy of Northwestern University</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML10]--><blockquote><p>Why cannot we write the entire 24 volumes of the <em>Encyclopædia Britannica</em> on the head of a pin? Let’s see what would be involved. The head of a pin is a sixteenth of an inch across. If you magnify it by 25,000 diameters, the area of the head of the pin is then equal to the area of all the pages of the <em>Encyclopædia Britannica</em>. Therefore, all it is necessary to do is to reduce in size all the writing in the <em>Encyclopædia</em> by 25,000 times. Is that possible? The resolving power of the eye is about 1/120 of an inch—that is roughly the diameter of one of the little dots on the fine half-tone reproductions in the <em>Encyclopædia</em>. This, when you demagnify it by 25,000 times, is still 80 angstroms in diameter—32 atoms across, in an ordinary metal. In other words, one of those dots still would contain in its area 1,000 atoms. So, each dot can easily be adjusted in size as required by the photoengraving, and there is no question that there is enough room on the head of a pin to put all of the <em>Encyclopædia Britannica</em>.</p></blockquote><p>Feynman was intrigued by biology and pointed out that</p><!--[P12]--><blockquote><p>cells are very tiny, but they are very active; they manufacture various substances; they walk around; they wiggle; and they do all kinds of marvelous things—all on a very small scale. Also, they store information. Consider the possibility that we too can make a thing very small which does what we want—that we can manufacture an object that maneuvers at that level!</p></blockquote><p>He also considered using big tools to make smaller tools that could make yet smaller tools, eventually obtaining nanoscale tools for directly manipulating atoms and molecules. In considering what all this might mean, Feynman declared,</p><!--[P14]--><blockquote><p>I can hardly doubt that when we have some control of the arrangement of things on a small scale we will get an enormously greater range of possible properties that substances can have, and of different things that we can do.</p></blockquote><p>Perhaps the biggest barrier to following these prophetic thoughts was simply the immediate lack of tools to manipulate and visualize matter at such a small scale. The availability of tools has always been an enabling aspect of the advance of all science and technology, and some of the key tools for nanotechnology are discussed in the next section, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/nanotechnology#ref236435" class="md-crosslink">Pioneers</a>.</p><!--[P16]--><p>Starting with a 1981 <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/paper" class="md-crosslink autoxref">paper</a> in the <em>Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences</em> and following with two popular books, <em>Engines of Creation</em> (1986) and <em>Nanosystems</em> (1992), American scientist <span id="ref836963"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/K-Eric-Drexler" class="md-crosslink">K. Eric Drexler</a> became one of the foremost advocates of nanotechnology. In fact, Drexler was the first person anywhere to receive a Ph.D. in molecular nanotechnology (from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology). In his written works he takes a molecular view of the world and <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/envisions" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="envisions">envisions</a> molecular machines doing much of the work of the future. For example, he refers to “assemblers,” which will manipulate individual atoms to manufacture structures, and “replicators,” which will be able to make multiple copies of themselves in order to save time dealing with the billions of atoms needed to make objects of useful size. In an article for Encyclopædia Britannica’s <em>1990 Yearbook of Science and the Future</em>, Drexler wrote:</p><!--[P17]--><blockquote><p>Cells and tissues in the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/human-body" class="md-crosslink autoxref">human body</a> are built and maintained by molecular machinery, but sometimes that machinery proves inadequate: viruses multiply, cancer cells spread, or systems age and deteriorate. As one might expect, new molecular machines and computers of subcellular size could support the body’s own mechanisms. Devices containing nanocomputers interfaced to molecular sensors and effectors could serve as an augmented <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/immune-system" class="md-crosslink autoxref">immune system</a>, searching out and destroying viruses and cancer cells. Similar devices programmed as repair machines could enter living cells to edit out viral DNA sequences and repair molecular damage. Such machines would bring surgical control to the molecular level, opening broad new horizons in <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/medicine" class="md-crosslink autoxref">medicine</a>.</p></blockquote><p>Drexler’s futurist visions have stimulated much thought, but the assembler approach has failed to account for the strong influence of atomic and molecular forces (i.e., the chemistry) at such dimensions. The controversy surrounding these popularizations, and the potential dangers of entities such as intelligent replicators (however remote), have stimulated debate over the <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/ethical" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="ethical">ethical</a> and societal <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/implications" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="implications">implications</a> of nanotechnology.</p><!--[P19]--></section><section id="ref236435" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2">Pioneers</h2><p>A number of key technological milestones have been achieved by working pioneers. <span id="ref836964"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/molecular-beam-epitaxy" class="md-crosslink">Molecular beam epitaxy</a>, invented by Alfred Cho and John Arthur at <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Bell-Laboratories" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Bell Labs</a> in 1968 and developed in the 1970s, enabled the controlled <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/deposition" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="deposition">deposition</a> of single atomic layers. This <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/tool" class="md-crosslink autoxref">tool</a> provided for nanostructuring in one dimension as atomic layers were grown one upon the next. It subsequently became important in the area of <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/compound" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="compound">compound</a> <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/semiconductor-device" class="md-crosslink autoxref">semiconductor device</a> fabrication. For example, sandwiching one-nanometre-thick layers of nonmagnetic-sensor materials between magnetic layers in computer disk drives resulted in large increases in storage capacity, and a similar use of nanostructuring resulted in more energy-efficient <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/laser#ref256344" class="md-crosslink">semiconductor lasers</a> for use in <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/compact-disc" class="md-crosslink autoxref">compact disc</a> players.</p><!--[P20]--><p>In 1981 <span id="ref836967"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Gerd-Binnig" class="md-crosslink">Gerd Binnig</a> and <span id="ref836968"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Heinrich-Rohrer" class="md-crosslink">Heinrich Rohrer</a> developed the <span id="ref836965"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/scanning-tunneling-microscope" class="md-crosslink">scanning tunneling microscope</a> at <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/International-Business-Machines-Corporation" class="md-crosslink">IBM</a>’s laboratories in Switzerland. This tool provided a revolutionary advance by enabling scientists to image the position of individual atoms on surfaces. It earned Binnig and Rohrer a <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Nobel-Prize" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Nobel Prize</a> in 1986 and spawned a wide variety of scanning probe tools for nanoscale observations.</p><!--[P21]--><p>The observation of new carbon structures marked another important milestone in the advance of nanotechnology, with Nobel Prizes for the discoverers. In 1985 <span id="ref836969"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Robert-F-Curl-Jr" class="md-crosslink">Robert F. Curl, Jr.</a>, <span id="ref836970"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Harold-Kroto" class="md-crosslink">Harold W. Kroto</a>, and <span id="ref836971"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Richard-Smalley" class="md-crosslink">Richard E. Smalley</a> discovered the first <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/fullerene" class="md-crosslink">fullerene</a>, the third known form of pure carbon (after diamond and graphite). They named their discovery <span id="ref836972"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/C60" class="md-crosslink">buckminsterfullerene</a> (“buckyball”) for its resemblance to the geodesic domes promoted by the American architect <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/R-Buckminster-Fuller" class="md-crosslink">R. Buckminster Fuller</a>. Technically called C<sub>60</sub> for the 60 carbon atoms that form their hollow spherical structure, buckyballs resemble a football one nanometre in diameter (<em>see</em> <span data-assembly-id="18013" class="md-link media-overlay-link">figure</span>). In 1991 <span id="ref836973"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Iijima-Sumio" class="md-crosslink">Sumio Iijima</a> of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/NEC-Corporation" class="md-crosslink">NEC Corporation</a> in Japan discovered <span id="ref836974"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/carbon-nanotube" class="md-crosslink">carbon nanotubes</a>, in which the carbon ringlike structures are extended from spheres into long tubes of varying diameter. Taken together, these new structures surprised and excited the imaginations of scientists about the possibilities of forming well-defined nanostructures with unexpected new properties.</p><!--[P22]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="18013"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/03/2403-004-32361ED8.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/03/2403-004-32361ED8.jpg" alt="The structure of buckminsterfullerene (C60)." data-width="296" data-height="349"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">The structure of buckminsterfullerene (C<sub>60</sub>).</span><cite>Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc.</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML22]--><p>The scanning tunneling microscope not only allowed for the imaging of atoms by scanning a sharp probe tip over a surface, but it also allowed atoms to be “pushed” around on the surface. With a slight bias voltage applied to the probe tip, certain atoms could be made to adhere to the tip used for imaging and then to be released from it. Thus, in 1990 Donald Eigler spelled out the letters of his company’s logo, <span id="ref836975"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/International-Business-Machines-Corporation" class="md-crosslink">IBM</a>, by moving 35 xenon atoms into place on a nickel surface. This demonstration caught the public’s attention because it showed the precision of the emerging nanoscale tools.</p><!--[P23]--></section></section><!--[H4]--><section id="ref236436" data-level="1"><h2 class="h1">Properties at the nanoscale</h2><p>At nanoscale dimensions the properties of materials no longer depend solely on composition and structure in the usual sense. Nanomaterials display new phenomena associated with quantized effects and with the preponderance of surfaces and interfaces.</p><!--[P24]--><p>Quantized effects arise in the nanometre regime because the overall dimensions of objects are comparable to the characteristic wavelength for fundamental excitations in materials. For example, electron <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/wave-function" class="md-crosslink">wave functions</a> (<em>see also</em> <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/de-Broglie-wave" class="md-crosslink">de Broglie wave</a>) in semiconductors are typically on the order of 10 to 100 nanometres. Such excitations include the wavelength of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/electron" class="md-crosslink">electrons</a>, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/photon" class="md-crosslink">photons</a>, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/phonon" class="md-crosslink">phonons</a>, and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/magnon" class="md-crosslink">magnons</a>, to name a few. These excitations carry the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/quantum" class="md-crosslink">quanta</a> of energy through materials and thus determine the <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/dynamics" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="dynamics">dynamics</a> of their <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/propagation" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="propagation">propagation</a> and transformation from one form to another. When the size of structures is comparable to the <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/quanta" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="quanta">quanta</a> themselves, it influences how these excitations move through and interact in the material. Small structures may limit flow, create wave interference effects, and otherwise bring into play quantum mechanical selection rules not apparent at larger dimensions.</p><!--[P25]--><section id="ref236437" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2">Electronic and photonic behaviour</h2><p>Quantum mechanical properties for confinement of electrons in one dimension have long been exploited in solid-state electronics. Semiconductor devices are grown with thin layers of differing composition so that electrons (or “holes” in the case of missing electron charges) can be confined in specific regions of the structure (known as quantum wells). Thin layers with larger energy bandgaps can serve as barriers that restrict the flow of charges to certain conditions under which they can “tunnel” through these barriers—the basis of resonant tunneling <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/diode" class="md-crosslink">diodes</a>. <span id="ref836978"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/superlattice" class="md-crosslink">Superlattices</a> are periodic structures of repeating wells that set up a new set of selection rules which affect the conditions for charges to flow through the structure. Superlattices have been exploited in cascade lasers to achieve far infrared wavelengths. Modern telecommunications is based on semiconductor lasers that exploit the unique properties of quantum wells to achieve specific wavelengths and high efficiency.</p><!--[P26]--><p>The propagation of <span id="ref836981"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/photon" class="md-crosslink">photons</a> is altered dramatically when the size and periodicity of the <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/transient" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="transient">transient</a> structure approach the wavelength of visible light (400 to 800 nanometres). When photons <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/propagate" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="propagate">propagate</a> through a periodically varying dielectric constant—for example, semiconductor posts surrounded by air—quantum mechanical rules define and limit the propagation of the photons depending on their energy (wavelength). This new behaviour is <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/analogous" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="analogous">analogous</a> to the quantum mechanical rules that define the motion of electrons through crystals, giving bandgaps for semiconductors. In one dimension, compound semiconductor superlattices can be grown epitaxially with the alternating layers having different dielectric constants, thus providing highly reflective mirrors for specific wavelengths as determined by the repeat distance of layers in the superlattice. These structures are used to provide “built-in” mirrors for vertical-cavity surface-emitting lasers, which are used in communications applications. In two and three dimensions, periodic structures known as photonic crystals offer additional control over photon propagation.</p><!--[P27]--><p>Photonic crystals are being explored in a variety of materials and periodicities, such as two-dimensional hexagonal arrays of posts fabricated in compound semiconductors or stacked loglike arrays of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/silicon" class="md-crosslink autoxref">silicon</a> bars in three dimensions. The dimensions of these structures depend on the wavelength of light being <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/propagated" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="propagated">propagated</a> and are typically in the range of a few hundred nanometres for wavelengths in the visible and near infrared. Photonic crystal properties based on nanostructured materials offer the possibility of confining, steering, and separating light by wavelength on unprecedented small scales and of creating new devices such as lasers that require very low currents to initiate lasing (called near-thresholdless lasers). These structures are being extensively investigated as the tools for nanostructuring materials are steadily advancing. Researchers are particularly interested in the infrared wavelengths, where dimensional control is not as stringent as at the shorter visible wavelengths and where optical communications and chemical sensing provide motivation for potential new applications.</p><!--[P28]--></section><section id="ref236438" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2">Magnetic, mechanical, and chemical behaviour</h2><p>Nanoscale materials also have size-dependent magnetic behaviour, mechanical properties, and chemical reactivity. At very small sizes (a few nanometres), magnetic nanoclusters have a single magnetic domain, and the strongly coupled magnetic spins on each atom combine to produce a particle with a single “giant” spin. For example, the giant spin of a ferromagnetic iron particle rotates freely at room temperature for diameters below about 16 nanometres, an effect termed <span id="ref836982"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/superparamagnetism" class="md-crosslink">superparamagnetism</a>. Mechanical properties of nanostructured materials can reach exceptional strengths. As a specific example, the introduction of two-nanometre <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/alumina" class="md-crosslink autoxref">aluminum oxide</a> precipitates into thin films of pure nickel results in yield strengths increasing from 0.15 to 5 gigapascals, which is more than twice that for a hard bearing steel. Another example of exceptional mechanical properties at the nanoscale is the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/carbon-nanotube" class="md-crosslink autoxref">carbon nanotube</a>, which exhibits great strength and stiffness along its longitudinal axis.</p><!--[P29]--><p>The preponderance of surfaces is a major reason for the change in behaviour of materials at the nanoscale. Since up to half of all the atoms in <span id="ref1219285"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/nanoparticle" class="md-crosslink">nanoparticles</a> are surface atoms, properties such as electrical transport are no longer determined by solid-state bulk phenomena. Likewise, the atoms in nanostructures have a higher average energy than atoms in larger structures, because of the large proportion of surface atoms. For example, catalytic materials have a greater chemical activity per atom of exposed surface as the catalyst is reduced in size at the nanoscale. Defects and impurities may be attracted to surfaces and interfaces, and interactions between particles at these small dimensions can depend on the structure and nature of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/chemical-bonding" class="md-crosslink autoxref">chemical bonding</a> at the surface. Molecular monolayers may be used to change or control surface properties and to mediate the interaction between nanoparticles.</p><!--[P30]--><p>Surfaces and their interactions with molecular structures are basic to all biology. The intersection of nanotechnology and <span id="ref836983"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/biotechnology" class="md-crosslink">biotechnology</a> offers the possibility of achieving new functions and properties with nanostructured surfaces. In this surface- and interface-dominated regime, biology does an exquisite job of selectively controlling functions through a combination of structure and chemical forces. The transcription of information stored in genes and the selectivity of biochemical reactions based on chemical recognition of complex molecules are examples where interfaces play the key role in establishing nanoscale behaviour. Atomic forces and chemical bonds dominate at these dimensions, while macroscopic effects—such as convection, turbulence, and momentum (inertial forces)—are of little consequence.</p><!--[P31]--></section></section><!--[H5]--><section id="ref236439" data-level="1"><h2 class="h1">Nanotechnology research</h2><section id="ref236440" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2">Nanomaterials</h2><p>As discussed in the section <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/nanotechnology#ref236436" class="md-crosslink">Properties at the nanoscale</a>, material properties—electrical, optical, magnetic, mechanical, and chemical—depend on their exact dimensions. This opens the way for development of new and improved materials through manipulation of their nanostructure. Hierarchical assemblies of nanoscale-engineered materials into larger structures, or their incorporation into devices, provide the basis for tailoring radically new materials and machines.</p><!--[P32]--><p>Nature’s assemblies point the way to improving structural materials. The often-cited <span id="ref836984"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/animal/abalone" class="md-crosslink">abalone</a> seashell provides a beautiful example of how the combination of a hard, brittle inorganic material with nanoscale structuring and a soft, “tough” organic material can produce a strong, durable nanocomposite—basically, these nanocomposites are made of calcium carbonate “bricks” held together by a glycoprotein “glue.” New engineered materials are emerging—such as polymer-clay nanocomposites—that are not only strong and tough but also lightweight and easier to recycle than conventional reinforced plastics. Such improvements in structural materials are particularly important for the transportation <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/industry" class="md-crosslink autoxref">industry</a>, where reduced weight directly translates into improved fuel economy. Other improvements can increase safety or decrease the impact on the environment of fabrication and recycling. Further advances, such as truly smart materials that signal their impending failure or are even able to self-repair flaws, may be possible with composites of the future.</p><!--[P33]--><p><span id="ref836985"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/sensor" class="md-crosslink">Sensors</a> are central to almost all modern control systems. For example, multiple sensors are used in automobiles for such <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/diverse" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="diverse">diverse</a> tasks as engine management, emission control, security, safety, comfort, vehicle monitoring, and diagnostics. While such traditional applications for physical sensing generally rely on microscale sensing devices, the advent of nanoscale materials and structures has led to new electronic, photonic, and magnetic <span id="ref836987"></span>nanosensors, sometimes known as “smart dust.” Because of their small size, nanosensors exhibit unprecedented speed and sensitivity, extending in some cases down to the detection of single molecules. For example, nanowires made of carbon nanotubes, silicon, or other semiconductor materials exhibit exceptional sensitivity to chemical species or biological agents. Electrical current through nanowires can be altered by having molecules attached to their surface that locally perturb their electronic band structure. By means of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/nanowire" class="md-crosslink autoxref">nanowire</a> surfaces coated with sensor molecules that selectively attach particular species, charge-induced changes in current can be used to detect the presence of those species. This same strategy is adopted for many classes of sensing systems. New types of sensors with ultrahigh sensitivity and specificity will have many applications; for example, sensors that can detect cancerous tumours when they consist of only a few cells would be a very significant advance.</p><!--[P34]--><p>Nanomaterials also make excellent filters for trapping heavy metals and other pollutants from industrial wastewater. One of the greatest potential impacts of nanotechnology on the lives of the majority of people on Earth will be in the area of economical water desalination and purification. Nanomaterials will very likely find important use in fuel cells, bioconversion for energy, bioprocessing of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/food" class="md-crosslink autoxref">food</a> products, waste remediation, and pollution-control systems.</p><!--[P35]--><p>A recent concern regarding nanoparticles is whether their small sizes and novel properties may pose significant health or environmental risks. In general, ultrafine particles—such as the carbon in photocopier toners or in soot produced by combustion engines and factories—have adverse respiratory and cardiovascular effects on people and animals. Studies are under way to determine if specific nanoscale particles pose higher risks that may require special regulatory restrictions. Of particular concern are potential carcinogenic risks from inhaled particles and the possibility for very small nanoparticles to cross the blood-brain barrier to unknown effect. Nanomaterials currently receiving attention from health officials include carbon nanotubes, buckyballs, and cadmium selenide quantum dots. Studies of the absorption through the skin of titanium oxide nanoparticles (used in sunscreens) are also planned. More far-ranging studies of the toxicity, transport, and overall fate of nanoparticles in ecosystems and the environment have not yet been undertaken. Some early animal studies, involving the introduction of very high levels of nanoparticles which resulted in the rapid death of many of the subjects, are quite controversial.</p><!--[P36]--></section><section id="ref236441" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2">Biomedicine and health care</h2><span id="ref236441" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref236442" data-level="3"><h2 class="h3"><span id="ref836988"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/drug-delivery" class="md-crosslink">Drug delivery</a></h2><p>Nanotechnology promises to impact medical treatment in multiple ways. First, advances in nanoscale particle design and fabrication provide new options for drug delivery and <span id="ref836989"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/pharmacotherapy" class="md-crosslink">drug therapies</a>. More than half of the new drugs developed each year are not water-soluble, which makes their delivery difficult. In the form of nanosized particles, however, these drugs are more readily transported to their destination, and they can be delivered in the conventional form of pills.</p><!--[P37]--><p>More important, nanotechnology may enable drugs to be delivered to precisely the right location in the body and to release drug doses on a predetermined schedule for optimal treatment. The general approach is to attach the drug to a nanosized carrier that will release the medicine in the body over an extended period of time or when specifically triggered to do so. In addition, the surfaces of these nanoscale carriers may be treated to seek out and become localized at a disease site—for example, attaching to cancerous tumours. One type of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/molecule" class="md-crosslink autoxref">molecule</a> of special interest for these applications is an organic <span id="ref836990"></span>dendrimer. A dendrimer is a special class of polymeric molecule that weaves in and out from a hollow central region. These spherical “fuzz balls” are about the size of a typical protein but cannot unfold like proteins. Interest in dendrimers derives from the ability to tailor their cavity sizes and chemical properties to hold different therapeutic agents. Researchers hope to design different dendrimers that can swell and release their drug on exposure to specifically recognized molecules that indicate a disease target. This same general approach to nanoparticle-directed drug delivery is being explored for other types of nanoparticles as well.</p><!--[P38]--><p>Another approach involves gold-coated nanoshells whose size can be adjusted to absorb light energy at different wavelengths. In particular, infrared light will pass through several centimetres of body tissue, allowing a delicate and precise heating of such capsules in order to release the therapeutic substance within. Furthermore, antibodies may be attached to the outer gold surface of the shells to cause them to bind specifically to certain tumour cells, thereby reducing the damage to surrounding healthy cells.</p><!--[P39]--></section><span id="ref236441" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref236443" data-level="3"><h2 class="h3"><span id="ref836991"></span>Bioassays</h2><p>A second area of intense study in <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/nanomedicine" class="md-crosslink autoxref">nanomedicine</a> is that of developing new diagnostic tools. Motivation for this work ranges from fundamental biomedical research at the level of single genes or cells to point-of-care applications for health delivery services. With advances in <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/molecular-biology" class="md-crosslink autoxref">molecular biology</a>, much diagnostic work now focuses on detecting specific biological “signatures.” These analyses are referred to as bioassays. Examples include studies to determine which genes are active in response to a particular disease or drug therapy. A general approach involves attaching fluorescing dye molecules to the target biomolecules in order to reveal their concentration.</p><!--[P40]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="video" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="220322"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="video"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/03/191203-049-8D5C0B54.jpg" alt="fluorescence; nanomedicine" data-width="426" data-height="240"></div></div><figcaption><strong class="md-assembly-title">fluorescence; nanomedicine</strong><span class="md-assembly-caption">Exploring the chemistry of fluorescence and its use as a nanomedical diagnostic tool.</span><cite>© American Chemical Society</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML40]--><p>Another approach to bioassays uses semiconductor nanoparticles, such as cadmium selenide, which emit light of a specific wavelength depending on their size. Different-size particles can be tagged to different receptors so that a wider variety of distinct colour tags are available than can be distinguished for dye molecules. The <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/degradation" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="degradation">degradation</a> in fluorescence with repeated excitation for dyes is avoided. Furthermore, various-size particles can be <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/encapsulated" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="encapsulated">encapsulated</a> in latex beads and their resulting wavelengths read like a <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/bar-code" class="md-crosslink">bar code</a>. This approach, while still in the exploratory stage, would allow for an enormous number of distinct labels for bioassays.</p><!--[P41]--><p>Another nanotechnology variation on bioassays is to attach one half of the single-stranded complementary DNA segment for the genetic sequence to be detected to one set of gold particles and the other half to a second set of gold particles. When the material of interest is present in a solution, the two attachments cause the gold balls to agglomerate, providing a large change in optical properties that can be seen in the colour of the solution. If both halves of the sequence do not match, no agglomeration will occur and no change will be observed.</p><!--[P42]--><p>Approaches that do not involve optical detection techniques are also being explored with nanoparticles. For example, magnetic nanoparticles can be attached to antibodies that in turn recognize and attach to specific biomolecules. The magnetic particles then act as tags and “handlebars” through which magnetic fields can be used for mixing, extracting, or identifying the attached biomolecules within microlitre- or nanolitre-sized samples. For example, magnetic nanoparticles stay magnetized as a single domain for a significant period, which enables them to be aligned and detected in a <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/magnetic-field" class="md-crosslink autoxref">magnetic field</a>. In particular, attached antibody–magnetic-nanoparticle combinations rotate slowly and give a distinctive magnetic signal. In contrast, magnetically tagged antibodies that are not attached to the biological material being detected rotate more rapidly and so do not give the same distinctive signal.</p><!--[P43]--><p><span id="ref837000"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/microfluidic-system" class="md-crosslink">Microfluidic systems</a>, or “labs-on-chips,” have been developed for biochemical assays of minuscule samples. Typically cramming numerous electronic and mechanical components into a portable unit no larger than a <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/credit-card" class="md-crosslink autoxref">credit card</a>, they are especially useful for conducting rapid analysis in the field. While these microfluidic systems primarily operate at the microscale (that is, millionths of a metre), nanotechnology has contributed new concepts and will likely play an increasing role in the future. For example, separation of <span id="ref837001"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/DNA" class="md-crosslink">DNA</a> is sensitive to entropic effects, such as the <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/entropy" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="entropy">entropy</a> required to unfold DNA of a given length. A new approach to separating DNA could take advantage of its passage through a nanoscale array of posts or channels such that DNA molecules of different lengths would uncoil at different rates.</p><!--[P44]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="video" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="208210"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="video"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/72/186372-049-2108C876.jpg" alt="materials science; wrinkle formation" data-width="426" data-height="240"></div></div><figcaption><strong class="md-assembly-title">materials science; wrinkle formation</strong><span class="md-assembly-caption">Creating wrinkled surfaces with precisely controlled sizes and patterns for use in various structures.</span><cite>© Massachusetts Institute of Technology</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML44]--><p>Other researchers have focused on detecting signal changes as nanometre-wide DNA strands are threaded through a nanoscale pore. Early studies used pores punched in membranes by viruses; artificially fabricated nanopores are also being tested. By applying an <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/electric-potential" class="md-crosslink autoxref">electric potential</a> across the membrane in a liquid <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/cell-biology" class="md-crosslink autoxref">cell</a> to pull the DNA through, changes in ion current can be measured as different repeating base units of the molecule pass through the pores. Nanotechnology-enabled advances in the entire area of bioassays will clearly impact health care in many ways, from early detection, rapid clinical analysis, and home monitoring to new understanding of molecular biology and genetic-based treatments for fighting disease.</p><!--[P45]--></section><span id="ref236441" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref236444" data-level="3"><h2 class="h3">Assistive devices and tissue engineering</h2><p>Another biomedical application of nanotechnology involves assistive devices for people who have lost or lack certain natural capabilities. For example, researchers hope to design retinal implants for vision-impaired individuals. The concept is to implant chips with photodetector arrays to transmit signals from the retina to the brain via the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/optic-nerve" class="md-crosslink">optic nerve</a>. Meaningful spatial information, even if only at a <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/rudimentary" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="rudimentary">rudimentary</a> level, would be of great assistance to the <span id="ref837002"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/blindness-medicine" class="md-crosslink">blind</a>. Such research illustrates the tremendous challenge of designing hybrid systems that work at the interface between inorganic devices and biological systems.</p><!--[P46]--><p>Closely related research involves implanting nanoscale neural probes in brain tissue to activate and control motor functions. This requires effective and stable “wiring” of many electrodes to neurons. It is exciting because of the possibility of recovery of control for motor-impaired individuals. Studies employing neural stimulation of damaged <span id="ref837003"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/spinal-cord" class="md-crosslink">spinal cords</a> by electrical signals have demonstrated the return of some locomotion. Researchers are also seeking ways to assist in the regeneration and healing of bone, skin, and cartilage—for example, developing synthetic biocompatible or biodegradable structures with nanosized voids that would serve as templates for regenerating specific tissue while delivering chemicals to assist in the repair process. At a more sophisticated level, researchers hope to someday build nanoscale or microscale machines that can repair, assist, or replace more-complex organs.</p><!--[P47]--></section></section><section id="ref236445" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2"><span id="ref837004"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/information-processing" class="md-crosslink">Information technology</a></h2><p>Semiconductor experts agree that the ongoing shrinkage in “conventional” electronic devices will inevitably reach fundamental limits due to quantum effects such as “tunneling,” in which electrons jump out of their prescribed circuit path and create atomic-scale interference between devices. At that point, radical new approaches to data storage and information processing will be required for further advances. For example, radically new systems have been imagined that are based on <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/quantum-computer" class="md-crosslink">quantum computing</a> or biomolecular computing.</p><!--[P48]--><span id="ref236445" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref236446" data-level="3"><h2 class="h3"><span id="ref837006"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/molecular-electronics" class="md-crosslink">Molecular electronics</a></h2><p>The use of molecules for electronic devices was suggested by Mark Ratner of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Northwestern-University-Evanston-Illinois" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Northwestern University</a> and Avi Aviram of IBM as early as the 1970s, but proper nanotechnology tools did not become available until the turn of the 21st century. Wiring up molecules some half a nanometre wide and a few nanometres long remains a major challenge, and an understanding of electrical transport through single molecules is only beginning to emerge. A number of groups have been able to demonstrate molecular switches, for example, that could conceivably be used in computer memory or logic arrays. Current areas of research include mechanisms to guide the selection of molecules, architectures for assembling molecules into nanoscale gates, and three-terminal molecules for transistor-like behaviour. More-radical approaches include <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/DNA-computing" class="md-crosslink autoxref">DNA computing</a>, where single-stranded DNA on a silicon chip would encode all possible variable values and complementary strand interactions would be used for a parallel processing approach to finding solutions. An area related to molecular electronics is that of organic thin-film <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/transistor" class="md-crosslink">transistors</a> and light emitters, which promise new applications such as video displays that can be rolled out like wallpaper and flexible electronic newspapers.</p><!--[P49]--></section><span id="ref236445" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref236447" data-level="3"><h2 class="h3"><span id="ref837009"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/carbon-nanotube" class="md-crosslink">Nanotubes</a> and <span id="ref837010"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/nanowire" class="md-crosslink">nanowires</a></h2><p>Carbon nanotubes have remarkable electronic, mechanical, and chemical properties. Depending on their specific diameter and the bonding arrangement of their carbon atoms, nanotubes exhibit either metallic or semiconducting behaviour. Electrical conduction within a perfect nanotube is <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/ballistic" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="ballistic">ballistic</a> (negligible scattering), with low thermal <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/dissipation" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="dissipation">dissipation</a>. As a result, a wire made from a nanotube, or a nanowire, can carry much more current than an ordinary metal wire of comparable size. At 1.4 nanometres in diameter, nanotubes are about a hundred times smaller than the gate width of silicon semiconductor devices. In addition to nanowires for conduction, transistors, diodes, and simple logic circuits have been demonstrated by combining metallic and semiconductor carbon nanotubes. Similarly, silicon nanowires have been used to build experimental devices, such as field-effect transistors, bipolar transistors, inverters, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/LED" class="md-crosslink">light-emitting diodes</a>, sensors, and even simple memory. A major challenge for nanowire circuits, as for molecular electronics, is connecting and <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/integrating" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="integrating">integrating</a> these devices into a workable high-density <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/architecture" class="md-crosslink autoxref">architecture</a>. Ideally, the structure would be grown and assembled in place. Crossbar architectures that combine the function of wires and devices are of particular interest.</p><!--[P50]--></section><span id="ref236445" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref236448" data-level="3"><h2 class="h3"><span id="ref837011"></span>Single-electron transistors</h2><p>At nanoscale dimensions the energy required to add one additional electron to a “small island” (isolated physical region)—for example, through a tunneling barrier—becomes significant. This change in energy provides the basis for devising single-electron transistors. At low temperatures, where thermal fluctuations are small, various single-electron-device nanostructures are readily achievable, and extensive research has been carried out for structures with confined electron flow. However, room-temperature applications will require that sizes be reduced significantly, to the one-nanometre range, to achieve stable operation. For large-scale application with millions of devices, as found in current <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/integrated-circuit" class="md-crosslink">integrated circuits</a>, the need for structures with very uniform size to maintain uniform device characteristics presents a significant challenge. Also, in this and many new nanodevices being explored, the lack of gain is a serious drawback limiting implementation in large-scale electronic circuits.</p><!--[P51]--></section><span id="ref236445" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref236449" data-level="3"><h2 class="h3"><span id="ref837012"></span>Spintronics</h2><p>Spintronics refers to electronic devices that perform logic operations based on not just the electrical charge of carriers but also their <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/spin-atomic-physics" class="md-crosslink">spin</a>. For example, information could be transported or stored through the spin-up or spin-down states of electrons. This is a new area of research, and issues include the injection of spin-polarized carriers, their transport, and their detection. The role of nanoscale structure and electronic properties of the ferromagnetic-semiconductor interface on the spin injection process, the growth of new ferromagnetic semiconductors with nanoscale control, and the possible use of nanostructured features to manipulate spin are all of interest.</p><!--[P52]--></section><span id="ref236445" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref236450" data-level="3"><h2 class="h3"><span id="ref837013"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/information-system" class="md-crosslink">Information storage</a></h2><p>Current approaches to information storage and retrieval include high-density, high-speed, solid-state electronic memories, as well as slower (but generally more spacious) magnetic and optical discs (<em>see</em> <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/computer-memory" class="md-crosslink">computer memory</a>). As the minimum feature size for electronic processing approaches 100 nanometres, nanotechnology provides ways to decrease further the bit size of the stored information, thus increasing density and reducing interconnection distances for obtaining still-higher speeds. For example, the basis of the current generation of magnetic disks is the giant magnetoresistance effect. A magnetic read/write head stores bits of information by setting the direction of the magnetic field in nanometre-thick metallic layers that alternate between ferromagnetic and nonferromagnetic. Differences in spin-dependent scattering of electrons at the interface layers lead to resistance differences that can be read by the magnetic head. Mechanical properties, particularly <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/tribology" class="md-crosslink autoxref">tribology</a> (friction and wear of moving surfaces), also play an important role in magnetic hard disk drives, since magnetic heads float only about 10 nanometres above spinning magnetic disks.</p><!--[P53]--><p>Another approach to information storage that is dependent on designing nanometre-thick magnetic layers is under commercial development. Known as <span id="ref837015"></span>magnetic random access memory (MRAM), a line of electrically switchable magnetic material is separated from a permanently magnetized layer by a nanoscale nonmagnetic interlayer. A resistance change that depends on the relative alignment of the fields is read electrically from a large array of wires through cross lines. MRAM will require a relatively small evolution from conventional semiconductor manufacturing, and it has the added benefit of producing nonvolatile memory (no power or batteries are needed to maintain stored memory states).</p><!--[P54]--><p>Still at an exploratory stage, studies of electrical conduction through molecules have generated interest in their possible use as memory. While still very speculative, molecular and nanowire approaches to memory are intriguing because of the small volume in which the bits of memory are stored and the effectiveness with which biological systems store large amounts of information.</p><!--[P55]--></section></section><section id="ref236451" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2">Communications</h2><p>Nanoscale structuring of optical devices, such as <span id="ref837016"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/vertical-cavity-surface-emitting-laser" class="md-crosslink">vertical-cavity surface-emitting lasers</a> (VCSELs), quantum dot lasers, and photonic crystal materials, is leading to additional advances in communications technology.</p><!--[P56]--><p>VCSELs have nanoscale layers of compound semiconductors epitaxially grown into their structure—alternating dielectric layers as mirrors and <span id="ref837018"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/quantum-well" class="md-crosslink">quantum wells</a>. Quantum wells allow the charge carriers to be confined in well-defined regions and provide the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/energy-conversion" class="md-crosslink autoxref">energy conversion</a> into light at desired wavelengths. They are placed in the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/laser" class="md-crosslink">laser</a>’s cavity to confine carriers at the nodes of a standing wave and to tailor the band structure for more efficient radiative recombination. One-dimensional nanotechnology techniques involving precise growth of very thin epitaxial semiconductor layers were developed during the 1990s. Such nanostructuring has <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/enhanced" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="enhanced">enhanced</a> the efficiency of VCSELs and reduced the current required for lasing to start (called the <span id="ref837020"></span>threshold current). Because of improving performance and their compatibility with planar manufacturing technology, VCSELs are fast becoming a preferred laser source in a variety of communications applications.</p><!--[P57]--><p>More recently, the introduction of <span id="ref837019"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/quantum-dot" class="md-crosslink">quantum dots</a> (regions so small that they can be given a single electric charge) into semiconductor lasers has been investigated and found to give additional benefits—both further reductions in <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/threshold" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="threshold">threshold</a> current and narrower line widths. Quantum dots further confine the optical emission modes within a very narrow spectrum and give the lowest threshold current densities for lasing achieved to date in VCSELs. The quantum dots are introduced into the laser during the growth of strained layers, by a process called <span id="ref837022"></span>Stransky-Krastanov growth. They arise because of the lattice mismatch stress and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/surface-tension" class="md-crosslink autoxref">surface tension</a> of the growing film. Improvements in ways to control precisely the resulting quantum dots to a more uniform single size are still being sought.</p><!--[P58]--><p>Photonic crystals provide a new means to control the steering and manipulation of photons based on periodic dielectric lattices with repeat dimensions on the order of the wavelength of light. These materials can have very exotic properties, such as not allowing light within certain wavelengths to be propagated in a material based on the particular periodic structure. Photonic lattices can act as perfect wavelength-selective mirrors to reflect back incident light from all orientations. They provide the basis for optical switching, steering, and wavelength separation on unprecedented small scales. The periodic structures required for these artificial crystals can be configured as both two- and three-dimensional lattices. Optical sources, switches, and routers are being considered, with two-dimensional planar geometries receiving the most attention, because of their greater ease of fabrication.</p><!--[P59]--><p>Another potentially important communications application for nanotechnology is <span id="ref837023"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/microelectromechanical-system" class="md-crosslink">microelectromechanical systems</a> (MEMS), devices sized at the micrometre level (millionths of a metre). MEMS are currently poised to have a major impact on communications via optical switching. In the future, electromechanical devices may shrink to nanodimensions to take advantage of the higher frequencies of mechanical vibration at smaller masses. The natural (resonant) frequency of vibration for small mechanical beams increases as their size decreases, so that little power is needed to drive them as oscillators. Their efficiency is rated by a quality factor, known as <em>Q</em>, which is a ratio of the energy stored per cycle versus the energy dissipated per cycle. The higher the <em>Q</em>, the more precise the absolute frequency of an oscillator. The <em>Q</em> is very high for micro- and nanoscale mechanical oscillators, and these devices can reach very high frequencies (up to microwave frequencies), making them potential low-power replacements for electronic-based oscillators and filters.</p><!--[P60]--><p>Mechanical <span id="ref837025"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/oscillator-electronics" class="md-crosslink">oscillators</a> have been made from silicon at dimensions of 10 × 100 nanometres, where more than 10 percent of the atoms are less than one atomic distance from the surface. While highly <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/homogeneous" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="homogeneous">homogeneous</a> materials can be made at these dimensions—for example, single-crystal silicon bars—surfaces play an increasing role at nanoscales, and energy losses increase, presumably because of surface defects and molecular species absorbed on surfaces.</p><!--[P61]--><p>It is possible to <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/envision" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="envision">envision</a> even higher frequencies, in what might be viewed as the ultimate in nanomechanical systems, by moving from nanomachined structures to molecular systems. As an example, multiwalled carbon nanotubes are being explored for their mechanical properties. When the ends of the outer nanotube are removed, the inner tube may be pulled partway out from the outer tube where <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/van-der-Waals-forces" class="md-crosslink">van der Waals forces</a> between the two tubes will supply a restoring force. The inner tube can thus oscillate, sliding back and forth inside the outer tube. The resonant frequency of oscillation for such structures is predicted to be above one gigahertz (one billion cycles per second). It is unknown whether connecting such systems to the macro world and protecting them from surface effects will ever be practical.</p><!--[P62]--></section></section><nav class="prev-next-pagination margin-top-50 margin-bottom-50 grid no-gutter  has-next">        <div class="pagination-control pagination-panel grid-xs ">                    </div>                    <div class="pagination-content pagination-panel grid-xs-shrink text-center text-uppercase">                Page 1 of 2            </div>                <div class="pagination-control pagination-panel text-right grid-xs has-link">                            <a href="/technology/nanotechnology/Nanofabrication" class="next grid no-gutter">                    <div class="grid-xs" data-layout="column">                        <small class="pagination-control-label text-uppercase">Next page</small>                        <span class="pagination-control-description text-ellipsis" title="Nanofabrication">Nanofabrication</span>                    </div>                    <i class="material-icons md-36 grid-xs-shrink middle-xs" data-icon="keyboard_arrow_right"></i>                </a>                    </div>    </nav></article><div class="md-learn-more extra-content" data-module="learn-more" data-value="learn-more">        <h2>Learn More <span>in these related Britannica articles:</span></h2>        <ul>        <li class="entry">                <a href="/technology/microelectromechanical-system">                    <div class="title"><strong>microelectromechanical system</strong></div>                    <div class="description"><e ty="b">Microelectromechanical system (MEMS)</e>,  mechanical parts and electronic circuits combined to form miniature devices, typically on a semiconductor chip, with dimensions from tens of micrometres to a few hundred micrometres (millionths of a metre).
